Award.AwardTitle: Catalyst Project: Indoor Moving Objects Trajectory Generation and Query Evaluation

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration: Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. This project at Tuskegee University seeks to develop an indoor data-based tracking framework designed to understand the mathematical and technological foundations of indoor data management. The project provides an opportunity for undergraduate students to enhance their education through research experiences in computer modeling and data management techniques. The researcher has established a strong collaboration with faculty at Auburn University. <br/><br/>This project will result in the development of a number of indoor query evaluation mechanisms and the techniques to derive the accurate locations of indoor moving items from raw erroneous indoor tracking data. This will improve the accuracy of indoor spatial queries, which can support many indoor high-level applications, including indoor location-based service and hotspot finding. Novel indoor tracking data management techniques will be devised. The goals of the project are to: 1) implement a simulation toolkit and a prototype system, where many indoor environments and deployment settings will be simulated for performance evaluation; 2) develop and compare a number of machine learning-based location inference methods for accurate trajectory generation in indoor environments; 3) design novel indoor query evaluation algorithms for various types of queries, in particular spatial query types such as range query and nearest neighbor query; and 4) invent an error model-based approach for indoor object trajectory tracking which is a non-machine learning approach. The results of this research will improve the performance of number of indoor location-based application which will make it easy to locate people and help to guide people to safety during emergency situations.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project's original title (PI: Dr. Asif Baba) was "Catalyst Project: Indoor Moving Objects Trajectory Generation and Query Evaluation", 

Due to the original PI leaving Tuskegee University and transferring to a non-HBCU institue, I inherited this grant. Having different research expertise and research focuses, the following changes were made to the title and scope of the project and accepted by Dr. Emanuel Waddell:

Title: An RFID Indoor Guidance System for the Visually Impaired to Provide a More Inclusive Experience in Educational Environments

Revised project goals/scope:

Goals:
1. Engaging Tuskegee University students in research involving the evaluation of the use of RFID technology as a means for indoor navigation for the visually impaired in an educational environment.

2. Engaging Tuskegee University students in research involving the comparison of the use of RFID technology to other means of indoor navigation for the visually impaired.

3. Engaging Tuskegee University students in building, testing, and evaluating an RFID prototype for indoor navigation for the visually impaired in an educational environment.

Scope:
This project aims to engage Tuskegee University students in research involving the use of RFID for accessibility. The project will potentially provide a more inclusive educational environment to the visually impaired by providing access to information typically offered through visual representation. We propose an RFID-based indoor guidance system to allow visually impaired students to access information as they navigate an educational environment such as a university building. Classrooms and office doors will be equipped with RFID tags to enable this. An accessible mobile application using text-to-speech will access and provide information related to rooms as they are passed. A visually impaired student will be informed of various information upon entering a building such as building name, floor, etc. As students pass rooms, they will be informed of their relative location and current classes in session. Students will also be informed of the location of a faculty/staff office as they pass it, any messages the faculty has posted, a brief description of any flyers posted. A department bulletin board can also be tagged where students can hear a brief description of all flyers posted.

Major outcomes:

1. The development of a voice based mobile application in Flutter for visually imparied individuals to allow those individuals to access information at their educational institutions such as virtual bulletin boards, virtual notes on office and classroom doors, and to leave notes in response to these messages through RFID.

2. The development of a web application for use by faculty and staff of an academic institution where they can post virutal notes to their offices, classrooms, and department bulletin boards. These notes are stored on a server and linked to specific RFID tags, that can be read through the Flutter mobile application being used by visually impaired individuals and utilizing RFID tags readers.

 

 

3. Tuskegee University students received training (took a course) and experience in mobile application development using Flutter. Students also gained experience in ReactJS web application development and building Java RESTFUL APIs. Students had the opportunity to engage in research related to RFID technologies used for indoor navigation, the pros, cons, and limitations of various technologies, and their integration into an educational environment and mobile applications.

4. Once the project is officially deployed, it will potentially impact areas of HCI and User Experience and offer insight and lessons in the accessibility of academic institutions and designing for accessibility using RFID. In addtion, the project contributes to equitable access to information typically posted on physical office doors, classrooms, and bulletin boards in educational institutions through the use of RFID and a voice-based mobile application. This results in a more inclusive approach that takes into consideration the needs of visually impaired individuals.
